TEI.2.document_title: Jonas Harrison to Stephen F Austin, 11-30-1832

barker_notes.barker_summary: Jonas Harrison to Austin, November 30, 1832. People of east Texas will gladly unite with San Felipe and Bexar to form provincial government for Texas as part of Mexican Confederation. No man of sense wants to separate from Mexico.
barker_notes.barker_footnotes: William H. Wharton was elected by the Convention of October, 1832, to take the petitions of the Convention to the government of Mexico. For the Convention, see Barker, The Life of Stephen F Austin, chapter XIII.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 895-896

text.body:
*div1 type="summary"* *p*Jonas Harrison to Austin, November 30, 1832. People of east Texas will gladly unite with San Felipe and Bexar to form provincial government for Texas as part of Mexican Confederation. No man of sense wants to separate from Mexico.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**location_mentioned*District of Teneha, Texas*/location_mentioned*,*/p*
*p**date_mentioned n="11-30-1832">November 30th 1832*/date_mentioned*.*/p* *p*Dear Sir,*/p*
*p*Your letter of the *date_mentioned n="11-18-1832">18th*/date_mentioned*, current came [to] hand *date_mentioned n="11-29-1832">late last evening*/date_mentioned*. The one you mention as giving an account of our "political situation," has not been received, nor any other except the one of the *date_mentioned n="11-18-1832">18th*/date_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*Rumor is busy with her thousand tongues, but we know nothing of the interior, not even whether *person_mentioned*Mr. Wharton*/person_mentioned* is gone or not.*/p*
*p*Our military elections are in a very unpleasant situation, and the *person_mentioned*sub committee of this *location_mentioned*district*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* have wrote to the *person_mentioned*Chairman of the central committee*/person_mentioned* on the subject; but we are fearful that he has not as yet received the letter.*/p*
*p*I am told that there is an opportunity of forwarding this letter by a *person_mentioned*Mr Burk*/person_mentioned* provided it is *location_mentioned*at the Big Road */location_mentioned*by twelve of the clock *date_mentioned n="11-30-1832">to-day*/date_mentioned*, but for this I should have taken your letter down and conversed with some of the *person_mentioned*principal citizens in the *location_mentioned*Aysh District*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* on the subject of it before I wrote you an answer. But as it is, I will with pleasure give you my opinion fully and frankly "that I think the *person_mentioned*Americans */person_mentioned*in *location_mentioned*these three districts */location_mentioned*would gladly embrace the project of uniting with the *person_mentioned*people of *location_mentioned*Bexar*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned* and *location_mentioned*the rest of Texas*/location_mentioned* in forming a *person_mentioned*provisional government*/person_mentioned* on the basis that *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned* is a part of the *location_mentioned*Mexican confederation*/location_mentioned*, and will so remain and that we are all *person_mentioned*Mexicans */person_mentioned*and will rigidly procet [protect] all the rights and interests of *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*. ["]*/p*
*p*The idea of a *person_mentioned*separate, distinct, and independent government*/person_mentioned* I do not believe exists in the mind of *person_mentioned*any man of common sense in the *location_mentioned*district*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned*. Nor do they want to belong to the *location_mentioned*United States of the North*/location_mentioned*, there are some fiew exceptions to this last opinion, but not many, scarsely one to ten.*/p*
*p*They have come to the *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*to participate of the benefits of the *location_mentioned*Mexican Independence*/location_mentioned*, and of their liberal policy in regard to land, and they wish to continue so. The idea of Texas being independent and forming a nation is absurd. The very expenses of supporting the Government could they have it, would render them the most oppressed people. Besides their weakness would invite aggression.*/p*
*p*They want a *person_mentioned*provisional Government*/person_mentioned*—they want a judiciary— the present system is little or no protection to their *person_mentioned*persons or property*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*I will write you more at large on this subject, but at present am in such fear of loosing the opportunity of conveyance, that I am not able to write as I other wise would*/p*.
*p*I hope you will continue to write and give me an account of the political complection of the *location_mentioned*interior*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*Be pleased to direct your letter to me at *location_mentioned*Teneha */location_mentioned*to be left at *location_mentioned**person_mentioned*Mr Philip */person_mentioned*Sublet's Big Road. Ayish District*/location_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*Be so good as to present my respects to *person_mentioned*Mr. Williams*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*J. Harrison*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p**person_mentioned*Colonel S. F. Austin*/person_mentioned**/p*
*/div1*
